boardgame.name: Beyond Bightwater
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The Bightwater Region is so named for its primary city, Bightwater, a port town. The region can be roughly broken into two eras. Many thousands of years ago, the area was a significant portion of the Eburnean Empire. This empire was both technologically and magically advanced, and many vestiges of their reign can still be found in the dark corners of the Bightwater region.

Following the fall of the empire (the ultimate cause of its fall was unknown) the more recent era saw the settlement of Bightwater by halfling merchants, who established a successful trade industry for several decades. Many wealthy halfling families thrived during this time, and their influence can still be felt today in the city. Roughly three human generations ago, barbarian invaders conquered and displaced many of the halflings. This resulted in a variety of different halfling settlements in the region. As the invaders began to settle in the newly-conquered region, certain halflings have returned to the city, its surrounding areas, and the trade industry. There remains a tense, uneasy peace between the city's inhabitants and surrounding settlements as a result of this history.

___

Beyond Bightwater is a system-neutral hex crawl. The project was a collaborative effort involving many from the RPGGeek community.

boardgame.name: Wobuga
boardgame.description:
Wobuga comes from WOrd BUilding GAme.

It includes 72 letters: 6 each for A, E, I, O; 4 each for U, Y; 2 each of all other letters.

To start, the letters are stirred face down, and each player draws 5 letters. A turn consists of drawing a letter and then either making a word out of one's hand, or adding one or more letters to words already on the table without rearranging their order. After playing, a player draws again and continues playing until announcing "I am thru", and the turn goes to the left. One can also make a sentence out of their own words, after which those words cannot be further altered. When a turn is over and other players see plays they could have done, they say "Wobuga" and can make the play for them and score the points they could have scored.

Points scored are: 5 points for each letter played during one's turn, 10 points for each word of a sentence, and 25 points for making the word "Wobuga". The highest score when all the letters are used wins.

There is also a solitaire mode where a player takes repeated turns and tries to use all the letters. Also, Wobuga Rush, where two players each play with a half deck in solitaire mode, and play through all their letters. Each player gets 5 points for each letter not used, and -10 points for being the first to say "I am thru"; the lower score wins.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Word for Word
boardgame.description:
Includes a deck of 61 cards having two sets of consonants (42) and three sets of vowels (15) (each letter having a point value), and four wild cards; plus a reference card showing the letter values, and a 1-minute sand timer.

Players have hands of 8 cards. The first player lays down a word from their hand of at least 3 cards. From then on, a turn is made by making a new word using at least one of the cards on the table, and at least on of the cards in the hand (the unused table cards are discarded), and drawing back up to an 8 card hand. The new word's score is the sum of the letter values newly laid down, with the older letters not scoring; except if all the table letters are used then the score is the entire word, doubled; if all the cards in hand are used in the new word the score is the entire word tripled.

The game ends when every player has had an equal number of turns after a player's score reaches a pre-determined total.

The solitaire game has the player playing cards to the table one at a time, either starting a new column (up to 5 columns), or adding a letter to an existing column. Two columns can also be combined end to end. Whenever a column forms a complete word it can be removed. The player wins if they can remove all the cards.

—user summary

boardgame.name: GenIsys Fantasy 4E
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

The Power you want with a familiar feel. This is a completely customizable system. You gain Character Points (CP) and you can buy abilities, skills capabilities, and even optional Arch Types. There is no limit to how far you can go.

GenIsys system relies on a 2d10 mechanic vs. a target number. Characters gain Action Dice to add a bit of luck when they need it.

A replacement for the failed alignment system that everyone keeps using is an all new Personality Profile.

You remember those games, “you wanted to be the most powerful wizard or the most badass fighter. Then you get up to 9th level and the campaign breaks down. GenIsys Fantasy allows you to take your character to all new heights of your character's ambition. Find the epic power you deserve, play GenIsys Fantasy.

What has changed:


The Equity system is now gone. You now just pay CP instead.
Ability Scores: We simplified the cost and progression.
The races CP cost for certain abilities with a CP-2 is all gone. The colubrine race is moving over to the Dark Races guide for those who want dark campaigns and we have added Centaurs, Cimmerian Elves and Halflings into the core book.
There are 4 Arch Types (Not Required). They are Clergy, Fighter, Magic User, and Scoundrel. They are especially helpful for new players or those who want to stay with a particular concept. There are several Specialties in each Arch Type and they each help your character become unique.
The number of skills has been reduced from 26 broad skills to 9. They have also been repackaged to better integrate with Arch Types.
The VPT system for spells is gone. We have replaced it with a simple maintenance mechanic, based on the Spell Casting Ability (SCA) of the spell you cast.
The spell system has been rewritten and is simplified, it is now so much easier to understand. The critical success/failure for each seed has been removed and streamlined.
Seeds now give you some supernatural benefits. e.g. The nature school gives you the ability to start speaking with nature and the higher your SCA in your Nature School, the better your communication with the creatures in nature.
Reworked Devotions, Rites and Rituals a bit. They are easier to use now.
Familiars have been simplified, and you can still have more than 1.
Cleaned up the rewards system and made it easier. Added more examples.

boardgame.name: Skruuvi
boardgame.description:
Skruuvi is a Finnish relative of Auction Whist (which is essentially Bridge without a dummy).

Like Bridge, it's a four player, partnership trick taking game. Players bid how many of the thirteen tricks their partnership can win (or, unlike Bridge, lose). Also, players can communication information about their hands through their bids (and, unlike Bridge, the cards they can exchange) with a system of conventions. Here are the main differences:


Players get to exchange cards with each other. There are two ways of playing Skruuvi depending on how players exchange cards: Kitty games and No-kitty games.


- In a Kitty game, players receive 12 cards; the four undealt cards is the kitty. The highest bidder adds the kitty to their hand, then gives any four cards to their partner. The partner adds these cards to their hand, then gives one card to each of the other three players.

- In a No-kitty game, players receive 13 cards. The highest bidder gives any four cards to their partner. The partner adds these cards to their hand, then returns any four cards back to the highest bidder.


Players optionally play several rounds of Bolshevik, where one player attempts to win or lose all 13 tricks (without a partner).



Players can bid misere, which is a bid of how many tricks a partnership will lose (without a trump suit).



As mentioned, there is no dummy!



As in Bridge, the lowest bid is to win 7 out of the 13 tricks. However, the lowest bid you can win the auction round is 11 tricks! (Or for misere bids, to lose 11 tricks!) In No-kitty games, the lowest bid is to win 12 out of the 13 tricks.



A game of Skruuvi lasts 24 rounds. Each player plays with a different partner for 8 rounds each.


—user summary

boardgame.name: after HOURS
boardgame.description:
after HOURS is a vignette, FMV game, that allows players a glimpse into the life of Lilith Grey – a young woman who was molested as a child and suffers from Borderline Personality Disorder as a result.

By spending a night alone with Lilith in her bedroom and subsequently, her head, players learn Lilith’s story by adopting a double gaze: that of the player witnessing Lilith’s story and piecing together why she behaves and responds as she does and to an extent, the gaze of Lilith herself.

This is achieved by having access to the voices in her head and the thoughts that respond to those voices. Hand drawn animations over the film serve to provide a more tactile experience of the game.

Source: The Publisher Website.
boardgame.videogamehonor: 2019 IGF Awards Best Student Game Winner
2019 IGF Awards Excellence in Narrative Nominee
